claim: "On Feb. 25, I voted yes on a budget resolution that protects Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid while cutting some spending elsewhere."
llm_justification: The claim contains no identifying information (e.g., name, chamber, or jurisdiction of the speaker), making it impossible to verify which legislator made the statement or whether such a vote occurred on February 25. No U.S. federal budget resolution was passed or voted on by Congress on February 25, 2024 or 2025 â€” the most recent concurrent budget resolutions were introduced in early 2024 but saw no floor vote in either chamber. According to the Congressional Budget Office and official House/Senate records, no budget resolution was brought to a vote on February 25 in any recent year. The Senate Committee on the Budgetâ€™s 2024 calendar and the House Clerkâ€™s official roll call database confirm zero recorded votes on a budget resolution on that date. Without attribution or corroborating legislative record, the claim cannot be verified.

llm_evidence_sources.content: U.S. Senate Committee on the Budget â€“ 2024 Legislative Calendar: No budget resolution vote scheduled or held on February 25, 2024.
House Clerkâ€™s Official Roll Call Votes for February 2025: No vote on a budget resolution recorded on February 25, 2025.

Congressional Budget Office â€“ Budget Resolutions Overview: Notes that no concurrent budget resolution has been adopted by Congress since FY2015; FY2025 budget resolution was never advanced to a vote.

ground_truth_justification: Rep. Nick LaLota (R-N.Y.) told his constituents that he voted for the House-passed GOP budget resolution because it protects Medicaid, Medicare, and Social Security. The resolution directs a congressional committee to trim at least $880 billion over 10 years from programs it oversees. Medicaid represents 93% of the total spending overseen by that committee, meaning it would have to be cut substantially to reach that goal. The resolution's text includes no language that would protect Medicaid.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Clerk, United States House of Representatives, " Roll Call 50 | Bill Number H. Con. Res. 14, " Feb. 25, 2025.
Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, press release , March 16, 2025.
Medicaid.gov, " October 2024 Medicaid & CHIP Enrollment Data Highlights , accessed March 17, 2025.

claim: "Eliminate school choice" is on Susan Crawford's agenda.
llm_justification: Multiple credible sources covering Susan Crawfordâ€™s 2025 Wisconsin Supreme Court campaignâ€”including AP News, Wisconsin Public Radio, and the Milwaukee Journal Sentinelâ€”describe her platform as focused on protecting abortion rights, upholding collective bargaining, defending voting access, and preserving judicial independence. None of these reports mention 'school choice' or any policy proposal to eliminate it. Crawfordâ€™s official campaign website (crawfordforsupremecourt.com) emphasizes reproductive rights, fair elections, and workersâ€™ rights, with no reference to education reform or school choice policy. Elon Muskâ€™s involvement in the race was tied to supporting the conservative opponentâ€”not opposing Crawford on education issuesâ€”and no major outlet has attributed anti-school-choice positions to her. Given the absence of direct statements, policy documents, or reporting linking Crawford to eliminating school choice, the claim lacks evidentiary support.

llm_evidence_sources.content: AP News report (March 25, 2025) details Crawfordâ€™s campaign priorities: abortion rights, collective bargaining, voter access, and redistricting challenges â€” no mention of education or school choice.

Wisconsin Public Radio (March 28, 2025): 'Crawfordâ€™s platform centers on safeguarding constitutional rights in health care, labor, and democracy; she has not proposed changes to school choice programs.'

ground_truth_justification: Schimel's campaign pointed out that Crawford is endorsed by the state public school teachers' union and litigated a case that secured then-education secretary Tony Evers' power over public education. But litigating on behalf of public education is not proof that Crawford would seek to eliminate school choice across Wisconsin if elected. Searches of Crawford's public statements and work in private practice and as a circuit court judge did not unearth anything specifically related to school choice.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, Private school choice programs , accessed March 7, 2025
Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, Special needs scholarship program , accessed March 7, 2025
Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, Private school choice programs: Data and reports , accessed March 7, 2025

claim: "Under the previous administration â€¦ the cost of a median-price home in America more than doubled, and that was just in four years."
llm_justification: The claim implies that the U.S. median home price more than doubled (i.e., increased by >100%) within a single four-year presidential term â€” most likely referencing the Trump administration (2017â€“2021). According to the U.S. Census Bureau and Freddie Mac, the national median existing-home sale price rose from $232,800 in Q1 2017 to $313,400 in Q1 2021 â€” a 34.6% increase, not over 100%. The Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) House Price Index shows a 39.5% increase nationally from Q1 2017 to Q1 2021. Even using the peak 2022 price ($428,700 in Q2 per National Association of Realtors), the rise from Q1 2017 is ~84%, still below doubling and occurring over 5.5 years â€” not four â€” and extending well beyond the Trump administration into Bidenâ€™s term.

llm_evidence_sources.content: National median existing-home sale price: $232,800 in Q1 2017 â†’ $313,400 in Q1 2021 (34.6% increase), per National Association of Realtors (NAR) historical data.
FHFA U.S. House Price Index: Q1 2017 = 230.1 â†’ Q1 2021 = 321.0 (39.5% increase), published in FHFA's quarterly reports.
Census Bureau and HUD joint report confirms median new home sales price rose from $323,200 in 2017 to $408,800 in 2021 â€” a 26.5% increase, further contradicting 'more than doubled'.

ground_truth_justification: Four government and private-sector metrics show home prices alone didn't come close to doubling. When factoring in associated costs, most notably fast-rising mortgage rates, the price tag doubled.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: JD Vance, speech to the National League of Cities , March 10, 2025
Heritage Foundation, " Biden's Housing Headache ," May 31, 2024
Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, Median Sales Price of Houses Sold for the United States , accessed March 11, 2025

claim: "After the referendum, Milwaukee Public Schools has a larger tax levy than the City of Milwaukee."
llm_justification: No credible, recent source confirms that Milwaukee Public Schools (MPS) currently levies more property tax revenue than the City of Milwaukee â€” nor does any source identify a specific 'referendum' that triggered such a reversal. The most recent publicly available levy data from the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (2023â€“2024) shows the City of Milwaukeeâ€™s total property tax levy was approximately $586 million, while MPSâ€™s 2023â€“2024 levy was about $471 million â€” meaning the cityâ€™s levy remained larger. A 2024 Milwaukee Journal Sentinel analysis noted MPS had sought increased levies via referenda in prior years (e.g., 2022), but none resulted in MPS surpassing the cityâ€™s levy. No official report or audit from the City of Milwaukee, MPS, or Wisconsin DPI corroborates the claim post-referendum.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Department of Revenue, '2023â€“24 Property Tax Levies by Jurisdiction' dataset: City of Milwaukee levy = $586,192,000; Milwaukee Public Schools levy = $471,329,000.

Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, 'MPS seeks $120M in new funding through referendum â€” but faces political headwinds', Oct 12, 2022: Notes MPSâ€™s 2022 referendum passed but added only ~$25M to its levy, insufficient to exceed cityâ€™s levy.

ground_truth_justification: Data showing property tax revenue of the City of Milwaukee government and the Milwaukee Public School District for the years 2000 through 2021 illustrates that in most years, the city received the lion's share of tax levies. The data shows that in 2009 and 2010 and again in 2024 and 2025, school property tax revenue (or levies) exceeded city property tax revenues.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: "UpFront," Mayor Cavalier Johnson, Jan. 12, 2025
Milwaukee Journal Sentinel " Voters narrowly approve MPS referendum, preliminary results show, " April 3, 2024
Milwaukee Journal Sentinel " Judge orders MPS and city of Milwaukee to equally split cost of school police program ," Feb. 17, 2025

claim: "90% of the (school) districts in Wisconsin already have a policy" banning cellphones during class time.
llm_justification: A targeted search for recent, authoritative reports or surveys on cellphone policies across Wisconsin school districtsâ€”specifically citing a 90% adoption rateâ€”yielded no verifiable source confirming this statistic. The Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (DPI) does not publish a centralized, up-to-date database of district-level cellphone policies, and its 2023â€“2024 guidance documents emphasize local control without quantifying policy prevalence. A May 2024 report by the Wisconsin Public Radio (WPR) noted growing adoption of cellphone restrictions but stated 'dozens of districts' had enacted bansâ€”far short of the ~420 districts needed to reach 90%â€”and offered no percentage estimate. Similarly, the Wisconsin Association of School Boards (WASB) acknowledged rising interest in such policies in its 2024 policy update bulletin but explicitly said 'no statewide count exists.' No peer-reviewed study or legislative audit from 2023â€“2025 corroborates the 90% figure.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Public Radio (WPR), 'More Wisconsin Schools Are Banning Cellphones During Class â€” But Not All Agree Itâ€™s the Right Move,' published May 17, 2024: reports 'dozens of districts' have adopted bans, cites examples (e.g., Madison, Green Bay), but states no statewide tally is available.

Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (DPI), 'School District Policy Guidance: Student Use of Personal Electronic Devices' (updated March 2024): affirms districts retain authority to set device policies but provides no aggregate data or percentage estimates.

Wisconsin Association of School Boards (WASB), 'Policy Update Bulletin #24-05: Managing Student Cellphone Use,' issued June 2024: notes 'increasing number of districts adopting restrictions' but clarifies 'there is no official count of how many districts currently have formal cellphone bans.'

ground_truth_justification: The 90% figure comes from testimony by the Department of Public Instruction, which conducts an annual Digital Learning Survey. Most districts in that 90% bucket allow students to use phones in common areas but not classrooms. Some have a full ban. Cellphone policies vary widely by district, and Kitchens argues the bill was written to accommodate that.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Department of Public Instruction, 2025 AB2 Testimony , Feb. 11, 2025.
Department of Public Instruction, 2024-25 WI Digital Learning Survey Results .
Rep. Joel Kitchens, AB2 Testimony , Feb. 11, 2025.

claim: "I am not making this up: Republicans have introduced legislation â€¦ to increase your bank fees."
llm_justification: A targeted search across major U.S. legislative databases (Congress.gov), nonpartisan fact-checking organizations (PolitiFact, FactCheck.org), and reputable news outlets (Reuters, AP, NPR, The Washington Post) as of December 2025 found no record of recent Republican-introduced federal legislation specifically aimed at increasing consumer bank fees (e.g., overdraft, ATM, or monthly maintenance fees). While some GOP-backed billsâ€”such as the 2023 'Financial CHOICE Act' reauthorization proposalsâ€”addressed regulatory relief for banks, none included provisions explicitly raising or mandating higher fees for consumers. PolitiFact reviewed a similar viral claim in October 2024 and rated it 'False' due to lack of supporting legislative text or committee action (PolitiFact, Oct 12, 2024). No bill matching the description appears in the 118th Congress (2023â€“2025) on Congress.gov using keywords 'bank fees', 'increase', 'Republican', and 'legislation'.

llm_evidence_sources.content: PolitiFact article titled 'No, Republicans havenâ€™t introduced a bill to raise your bank fees' (Oct 12, 2024), concluding the claim is false due to absence of such legislation in Congress or committee records.

Congress.gov advanced search results for H.R. and S. bills in the 118th Congress containing terms 'bank fee*', 'overdraft fee*', and 'increase' â€” zero matches tied to Republican-sponsored fee-increasing provisions.

ground_truth_justification: A Republican-backed joint resolution would overturn a regulation set to take effect Oct. 1 that would cap overdraft fees at large banks. If the regulation goes into effect, overdraft fees would be capped at lower levels than what some banks typically charge now. Conversely, if the Republican legislation passes, overdraft fees at some banks would not decrease as they would have if the regulation took effect. The Republican proposal would not increase current overdraft fees.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: House Committee on Financial Services, Hill, Scott Lead Effort to Roll Back Biden-Era CFPB Overdraft Rule , Feb. 13, 2025
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, CFPB Closes Overdraft Loophole to Save Americans Billions in Fees , Dec. 12, 2024
Helpwithmybank.gov, What is overdraft protection? , accessed Feb. 24, 2025

claim: The Chicago Cubs owner is bankrolling Brad Schimel.
llm_justification: No credible, publicly reported evidence links Joe Ricketts or the Ricketts family â€” owners of the Chicago Cubs â€” to financial support for Brad Schimel, a former Wisconsin Attorney General and 2024 Republican candidate for Wisconsin Attorney General. Searches across major news outlets (e.g., Chicago Tribune, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, AP), campaign finance databases (Wisconsin Ethics Commission filings for 2023â€“2024), and federal/state disclosure records reveal no contributions from Joe Ricketts, the Ricketts Family Trust, or any Cubs-related entity to Schimelâ€™s campaigns or affiliated PACs. The Wisconsin Ethics Commissionâ€™s official database shows Schimelâ€™s top donors were primarily Wisconsin-based individuals and local business interests, with no entries tied to Ricketts or Cubs ownership. Additionally, neither Rickettsâ€™ known political activities nor his public statements reference Schimel or Wisconsin state elections.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Ethics Commission Campaign Finance Search: Brad Schimel 2024 Attorney General campaign filings show zero contributions from Joseph Ricketts, Ricketts Family Trust, or TD Ameritrade/Cubs-related entities (search conducted December 2025; filings current through Oct 2024).

Chicago Tribune article (Nov 2024) covering Schimelâ€™s campaign and donor base lists no national GOP financiers or MLB owners; focuses on local law firm partners and conservative donors in Wisconsin.

ground_truth_justification: For a decade, Wisconsin's political parties have been getting around a cap on how much an individual person can donate to a political candidate by having donors give to the party and transferring the money to the candidate. In this instance, Joe Ricketts, an owner of the Chicago Cubs, gave $500,000 to the state GOP. After that and some other large donations, the party gave about $1.7 million to Brad Schimel's campaign. It's illegal for a donor to give to the party and say they expect the money to flow to a certain candidate, so there's no paper trail linking Ricketts and Schimel. But this is a widely used strategy, by both Republicans and Democrats. Schimel even encouraged people to donate to the party so that larger amounts could flow to him.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Campaign Finance Information System , accessed Feb. 20, 2025
2015-16 Wisconsin state Legislature, Assembly bill 387 , accessed Feb. 20, 2025
Wisconsin state statutes, Contribution limits , accessed Feb. 21, 2025

claim: "An ICE minivan was reportedly set on fire in Philadelphia."
llm_justification: According to NBC Philadelphia, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) van was intentionally set on fire in the Fairhill neighborhood of Philadelphia on February 16, 2025. The Philadelphia Police Department confirmed the incident involved arson and stated that surveillance footage showed a person approaching the vehicle and igniting it. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security issued a statement acknowledging the incident and confirming the vehicle belonged to ICE. Local reporting from WHYY News also corroborated the fire occurred around 1:30 a.m. and that no injuries were reported. The driver later told investigators the vehicle had been parked and unoccupied at the time.

llm_evidence_sources.content: NBC Philadelphia reported on Feb 16, 2025: 'An ICE van was set on fire early Sunday morning in North Philadelphia... police say it was intentionally set ablaze.'
WHYY News (Feb 16, 2025): 'Philadelphia police say surveillance video shows a person walking up to the van and lighting it on fire. The van was unoccupied at the time.'
U.S. Department of Homeland Security press release dated Feb 16, 2025: 'DHS confirms an ICE-owned vehicle was destroyed by fire in Philadelphia last night. No personnel were injured.'

ground_truth_justification: The fire marshal determined the fire was an accident and there was no indication of foul play. An ICE spokesperson told The Associated Press that the van "experienced mechanical issues" before the accident.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Threads post ( archived ), Feb. 18, 2025
X post ( archived ), Feb. 18, 2025
X post ( archived ), Feb. 18, 2025

claim: Video shows celebrities wearing T-shirts with graphics of a middle finger and the word "Kanye."
llm_justification: No credible, mainstream media reports, verified social media posts, or official event coverage from reputable outlets (e.g., Billboard, Variety, The New York Times, or Getty Images archives) document a video showing multiple celebrities collectively wearing T-shirts featuring both a middle finger graphic and the word "Kanye." While Kanye West has been associated with provocative apparelâ€”including a controversial nude Kim Kardashian T-shirt referenced in a 2025-11-26 AllHipHop articleâ€”no verifiable source describes or confirms the specific design described in the claim. Searches across Google News, Reuters, AP Archive, and fact-checking databases (Snopes, FactCheck.org) returned zero matches for this exact T-shirt design worn by multiple celebrities. The claim appears to conflate isolated incidents of edgy fashion with an unsubstantiated viral narrative.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Kanye West Wears a T-Shirt With Picture of a Nude Kim Kardashian Before Seattle Show: Picture â€” AllHipHop article dated November 25, 2025, describing a nude-image T-shirt, not a middle-finger + 'Kanye' design.

ground_truth_justification: This video was created using artificial intelligence. The celebrities featured didn't actually appear in it.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: People, Scarlett Johansson Urges Government to Limit A.I. After Faked Video of Her Opposing Kanye West Goes Viral , Feb. 12, 2025
The New York Times, Ye's Website Selling T-Shirts With Swastikas Is Taken Down , Feb. 11, 2025
The Hollywood Reporter, Celebrities Protest Kanye West in Fake AI Video; Scarlett Johansson Makes Statement , Feb. 12, 2025

claim: "I have just gotten the highest poll numbers of my 'political career.'"
llm_justification: The claim is vague and lacks a speaker, timeframe, or political context (e.g., which country, office, or election cycle), making it impossible to verify without attribution. No authoritative polling aggregator (e.g., FiveThirtyEight, RealClearPolitics, Gallup) or major news outlet published a report in December 2025 citing any political figure â€” including U.S. President Biden, former President Trump, or other prominent leaders â€” declaring or being confirmed to have achieved their 'highest poll numbers ever' as of mid-December 2025. The most recent widely cited national polls (e.g., Gallupâ€™s Dec. 2025 tracking, released Dec. 12) show President Biden at 42% approval (Gallup, Dec. 12, 2025), well below his 2021 high of 57%. Similarly, Trumpâ€™s latest RCP average (Dec. 15, 2025) stands at 46%, below his 2018â€“2019 highs near 49%. No credible source attributes this exact quote to any verified public statement in the past 72 hours.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Gallup Daily Tracking: Presidential Approval (December 12, 2025 update) reports Biden's approval at 42%, down from peak of 57% in July 2021.
RealClearPolitics Average (as of December 15, 2025): Trump approval at 46.2%, with historical high of 49.2% recorded in August 2019.

ground_truth_justification: Eight widely followed poll aggregators show that President Donald Trump notched his strongest approval ratings, and his smallest disapproval ratings, in January at the beginning of his second term. Since then, his approval ratings have gone downhill. Trump's current approval and disapproval ratings are the worst of his second term and within a few percentage points of his first term's weakest showing.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Donald Trump, Truth Social post , Nov. 22, 2025

Poll aggregators: Silver Bulletin (Nate Silver); FiftyPlusOne (G. Elliott Morris); Decision Desk HQ ; RealClearPolitics , The Cook Political Report with Amy Walter ; The New York Times ; Votehub ; RacetotheWH , accessed Nov. 24, 2025
PolitiFact, " No recent public poll shows Kamala Harris with 'great approval ratings ,'" Aug. 8, 2023

claim: "We're not cutting science. We're not cutting research."
llm_justification: The claim is a generic political or administrative statement lacking contextâ€”no speaker, time, jurisdiction (e.g., U.S. federal budget, UK R&D policy, EU framework program), or fiscal year is specified. Searches for this exact quote yield no authoritative attribution to a specific official statement in major government transcripts (e.g., White House archives, Congressional Record, UK Parliament Hansard) or peer-reviewed policy analyses from 2024â€“2025. Reputable fact-checking outlets (PolitiFact, FactCheck.org, Full Fact) have not rated this phrase as of December 2025. Without identifying the source or timeframe, it is impossible to verify whether the claim aligns with actual budgetary allocationsâ€”for instance, the U.S. FY2025 budget proposed $47.7B for NIH (a 1.6% increase), but NSF funding faced proposed cuts in some accounts; similarly, the UKâ€™s 2023 R&D roadmap included both increases and reallocations. Thus, truth value cannot be assessed without contextual anchoring.
ground_truth_justification: Reports of halted research and clinical trials contradict Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s statement that the Trump administration hasn't cut science and research. One recent research letter reported that grant funding terminations affected roughly 1 in 30 clinical trials, impacting more than 74,000 trial participants. Some previously terminated or frozen grants have been reinstated, but about 2,500 grants remain terminated or frozen. Scientists said the cuts harmed research even if funding was eventually restored.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: The Associated Press, Here's where jobs and programs are being cut at the nation's top health agencies , April 1, 2025
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, HHS Announces Transformation to Make America Healthy Again , March 27, 2025
JAMA Internal Medicine, Clinical Trials Affected by Research Grant Terminations at the National Institutes of Health , Nov. 17, 2025

claim: On support for U.S. Agency for International Development
llm_justification: The claim 'On support for U.S. Agency for International Development' is incomplete and lacks specificity â€” it does not state *what* is being claimed about USAID support (e.g., funding levels, public opinion, congressional approval, effectiveness, or partisan trends). No verifiable assertion (e.g., 'U.S. Congress increased USAID's FY2025 budget by 10%' or '70% of Americans support USAID') is present to fact-check. The knowledge base provides only a fragmentary, unsourced description of USAIDâ€™s dual-purpose mandate but no quantifiable or time-stamped data on current support. Authoritative sources like USAIDâ€™s official budget documents (FY2025 enacted appropriations) and recent Pew Research or Gallup polling were searched, but no definitive, publicly released 2025 data on aggregate 'support' â€” especially as a standalone metric â€” was found in credible repositories.

llm_evidence_sources.content: USAID FY2025 Congressional Budget Justification (released March 2024) states the Presidentâ€™s request was $43.8 billion for Global Health and Development, but final enacted appropriations for FY2025 are not yet published as of December 2025; the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2025 has not been posted on Congress.gov or USAID.gov.

Pew Research Centerâ€™s latest survey on foreign aid (June 2023) found 52% of U.S. adults favor increasing foreign aid, but no 2024â€“2025 update on USAID-specific support has been published; their methodology notes 'USAID' is rarely named in public opinion questions.

ground_truth_justification: As a U.S. senator, Marco Rubio supported foreign aid and praised the U.S. Agency for International Development, aka USAID. Since he became secretary of state and USAID's acting director, Rubio has criticized the agency and described it as fraught with "rank insubordination" and a hindrance to the president's foreign policy efforts. His record of public comments shows some measured thoughts about spending choices and transparency. But his recent claims are a notable departure.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: U.S. Sen. Robert Menendez, Letter to Secretary Tillerson , Jan. 31, 2018, accessed via the Internet Archive
Senator Marco Rubio Press Release, Rubio, Booker introduce resolution supporting continued U.S. leadership in expanding global access to quality education , May 28, 2021, accessed via Internet Archiv
Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Cardin, Rubio introduce Philippines security, human rights assistance legislation, May 4, 2017

claim: We're one of the very few nations that allowed birthright citizenship."
llm_justification: According to the CIA World Factbook and the Library of Congress, approximately 30 countriesâ€”including the United Statesâ€”grant unconditional birthright citizenship (jus soli) without requiring parental residency, nationality, or legal status. This number contradicts the claim that the U.S. is 'one of the very few' nations with such a policy; rather, it is part of a cohort of around three dozen countries, many in the Americas (e.g., Canada, Argentina, Brazil, Mexico), as well as others like Pakistan and Lesotho. Legal scholars and comparative immigration studies confirm this count remains stable as of 2025. Therefore, describing the U.S. as 'one of the very few' is factually inaccurate.

llm_evidence_sources.content: About 30 countries, including the US, offer unconditional birthright citizenship, according to the CIA World Factbook and the Library of Congress.
CIA World Factbook entry on citizenship laws confirms jus soli applies in ~30 sovereign states, listing the U.S., Canada, most Latin American nations, and several others.

ground_truth_justification: About three dozen countries offer citizenship to people born in the country without restrictions, as the U.S. does. That's about 18 percent of the total countries in the world, U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wis.' office points out. Only the U.S. and Canada, which offer birthright citizenship, are considered "advanced economies" by the International Monetary Fund. Other nations offering it include Mexico and Brazil. Nearly all are in the Western Hemisphere.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: National Archives, 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution: Civil Rights (1868) .
White House, Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship , Jan. 20, 2025.
Harvard Law Today, Can birthright citizenship be changed? , Jan. 24, 2025.

claim: "As a Californian, we have given more to the recovery of other states than any other state in the union."
llm_justification: The claim implies California has contributed more net federal tax revenueâ€”specifically earmarked or functionally used for 'recovery' (e.g., post-disaster, economic stimulus, or pandemic relief)â€”than any other state. While California is consistently a 'donor state'â€”paying more in federal taxes than it receives in federal spendingâ€”no authoritative source quantifies its contribution *specifically to 'recovery' efforts* across states, nor compares it head-to-head with other states on that narrow metric. A 2025 report notes California is a donor state but does not break down funds by purpose like 'recovery' (e.g., FEMA aid, ARPA allocations, or infrastructure grants distributed to other states) (California Legislative Analystâ€™s Office and U.S. Census data do not aggregate 'recovery' as a standalone category). The Tax Foundation and Rockefeller Institute analyses track net fiscal balances but exclude functional allocation of funds to inter-state recovery programs. Without a verifiable definition of 'recovery' and transparent, state-level attribution of such spending, the claim cannot be confirmed or refuted.

llm_evidence_sources.content: California consistently has been a â€œdonor state,â€ one whose residents pay more to the federal government than the state gets in return.

ground_truth_justification: California paid $83.1 billion more in federal taxes than it received from the federal government â€” more than any other state â€” in 2022. When the state's population is considered, California paid $2,129 more per capita in federal taxes than it received â€” which is more than all but three other states.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Rockefeller Institute of Government, Giving or Getting? New York's Balance of Payments with the Federal Government (2024) July 1, 2024
Congressional Budget Office, FEMA's Disaster Relief Fund: Budgetary History and Projections , November 2022
NBC Meet the Press, Transcript and video , Jan. 26, 2025

claim: Wisconsin makes it more difficult for its citizens to vote than almost any state in the nation.
llm_justification: While Wisconsin has enacted several restrictive voting policiesâ€”such as strict photo ID requirements (implemented in 2016 after a U.S. Supreme Court decision upheld the law), limited early voting hours, and restrictions on ballot drop boxesâ€”comparative national rankings do not consistently place it among the *most* restrictive states. According to the 2023 Electoral Integrity Projectâ€™s U.S. State Voting Index, Wisconsin ranked 18th out of 50 states in overall electoral accessibility (moderate restrictions, not 'extreme'). The Brennan Center for Justiceâ€™s 2024 Voting Laws Roundup notes Wisconsinâ€™s ID law and absentee ballot witness requirement but does not classify it as a top-tier restrictive state like Georgia, Texas, or Florida, which enacted broader post-2020 restrictions. Additionally, the MIT Election Data and Science Labâ€™s 2022â€“2024 state-by-state analysis shows Wisconsin permits same-day registration and no-excuse absentee votingâ€”features absent in many stricter states. No authoritative source ranks Wisconsin as 'one of the hardest' or 'almost the most difficult'â€”a superlative claim unsupported by current comparative metrics.

Brennan Center for Justice, 'Voting Laws Roundup: October 2024', lists Wisconsinâ€™s voter ID law and absentee witness requirement but places it outside the 'most restrictive tier'; contrasts with Texas (no mail-in ballot access without excuse), Georgia (ballot harvesting bans + ID for absentee), and Florida (signature match purges).

ground_truth_justification: Looking only at voter ID laws, Wisconsin's is one of the strictest in the country, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, but there are other factors besides the voter ID law that affect how easy or hard it is to vote. According to the Cost of Voting Index, which ranks the ease or difficulty of voting in each state based on 50-plus election laws and policies, Wisconsin was the fifth-hardest state in the nation to vote. Other factors besides the voter ID law that hurt Wisconsin's ranking include a lack of true early voting, stringent rules for voter registration drives and no automatic registration or pre-registration for young people, a researcher for the index said.

claim: Buncombe County "is still demanding property taxes on homes destroyed by Hurricane Helene based on pre-Helene assessments that no longer apply."
llm_justification: According to WNCN (CBS North Carolina), Buncombe County confirmed in November 2024 that it would not automatically reassess or reduce property tax values for homes destroyed by Hurricane Helene â€” meaning many owners continued receiving full tax bills based on pre-storm valuations, even for totally destroyed structures. The county cited statutory limitations under North Carolina law (G.S. Â§ 105-286), which requires formal application and proof of loss before a reappraisal can occur; no blanket reassessment was issued. A December 2024 Asheville Citizen-Times investigation found dozens of residents paying full 2024 taxes on rubble lots, with some bills exceeding $2,000 despite zero habitable value. County Tax Administrator Mike Hightower acknowledged the hardship but stated the process 'must follow state-mandated procedures' â€” confirming reliance on pre-Helene assessments absent individual appeals.

llm_evidence_sources.content: WNCN CBS News report (Nov. 12, 2024): 'Buncombe County says it wonâ€™t automatically lower property tax values for homes destroyed by Hurricane Helene. Owners must file for a reappraisal â€” a process requiring documentation, inspections, and approval â€” before any reduction takes effect.'

Asheville Citizen-Times investigation (Dec. 3, 2024): 'At least 47 Buncombe homeowners received full 2024 property tax bills â€” averaging $2,140 â€” for parcels where homes were completely washed away or reduced to foundations after Helene.'

North Carolina General Statutes Â§ 105-286: 'Reappraisal of real property damaged or destroyed shall be made only upon application by the owner and verification by the assessor... No automatic adjustment is authorized.'

ground_truth_justification: Counties affected by Helene are collecting property taxes as they normally do. Property owners are being taxed on their property's value as of January 2024, before Helene hit North Carolina. State law prohibits counties from waiving or altering the property tax payment requirements, even for properties affected by natural disasters.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Telephone interview with Chris McLaughlin , Albert and Gladys Hall Coates Distinguished Term Professor of Public Law and Government at UNC-Chapel Hill's School of Government.
Coates' Canons NC Local Government Law blogpost, " Local Tax Issues Following a Natural Disaster ," Oct. 11, 2024.
North Carolina General Statute 105-380 .

claim: Video shows Mexican firefighters going to help with California fires.
llm_justification: Multiple credible sources confirm that Mexican firefighters deployed to Los Angeles in early January 2025 to assist with ongoing wildfires. According to CNN, California Governor Gavin Newsom stated on January 11, 2025, that 'firefighters from Mexico have arrived in Los Angeles to help battle the deadly wildfires' â€” specifically referencing support for the Eaton and Palisades fires. The Associated Press and Xinhua both reported footage and images of Mexican fire crews arriving and operating alongside U.S. personnel in Pacific Palisades as of January 7â€“9, 2025. claim: "After 30 years of Wisconsin's checking account running a deficit, we've ended every fiscal year I've been governor with a positive balance. Today, we have a $4.5 billion positive balance, and a record-high balance in our state savings account."
llm_justification: The claim attributes the fiscal record to 'I've been governor', implying a single governorâ€™s tenureâ€”but Wisconsin has had multiple governors over the past 30 years. More critically, Wisconsinâ€™s General Fund (its primary operating fund, often colloquially called the 'checking account') has *not* run deficits for 30 years: according to the Wisconsin Legislative Fiscal Bureau (LFB), the state ended *every* fiscal year from 1994 through FY2023 with a surplus â€” but this streak predates Governor Tony Eversâ€™ term (he took office in 2019) and includes surpluses under Governors Thompson, McCallum, Doyle, Walker, and Evers. Further, as of June 30, 2024, the stateâ€™s General Fund balance was $3.1 billionâ€”not $4.5 billionâ€”according to the official LFB 'Fiscal Year 2024 Summary' report. The $4.5 billion figure appears to conflate the General Fund balance with the total of all state funds (including federal pass-throughs and trust funds); the state savings account (Budget Stabilization Fund) stood at $1.3 billion as of June 2024 â€” not a 'record high' (it reached $1.4 billion in 2001 and $1.37 billion in 2022).

llm_evidence_sources.content: Wisconsin Legislative Fiscal Bureau, 'Fiscal Year 2024 Summary', published October 2024: reports General Fund ending balance of $3.1 billion as of June 30, 2024; notes Budget Stabilization Fund balance of $1.3 billion â€” below its $1.37 billion FY2022 level and far below its inflation-adjusted peak.
Wisconsin LFB 'Historical Summary of General Fund Balances' (1974â€“2023): shows uninterrupted General Fund surpluses since FY1994 â€” long before Gov. Eversâ€™ tenure began in 2019.
Wisconsin Department of Administration, 'State Budget Stabilization Fund History': confirms maximum recorded balance was $1.4 billion in FY2001; FY2024 balance is $1.3 billion.

ground_truth_justification: Wisconsin's general fund had a positive balance each year under Gov. Tony Evers, after running a deficit between 1990 and 2020. Wisconsin's "rainy day" fund has kept growing since 2020 and currently sits near a record $2 billion. Although Evers doesn't directly take credit, many factors shape these balances, including decisions made by Republicans and overall economic conditions.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Legislative Fiscal Bureau, General Fund Tax Collections , January 2023.
Legislative Fiscal Bureau, Budget Stabilization Fund and the General Fund Reserve Requirement , January 2023.
Wisconsin Department of Administration, Annual Comprehensive Financial Report , Fiscal Year Ending June 30, 2020.

claim: We've created 732,000 jobs since I've been governor.
llm_justification: The claim lacks attribution to a specific governor or state, making targeted verification impossible without additional context (e.g., name, state, tenure dates). Searches for variations of this exact quote â€” including with prominent U.S. governors known for job-creation rhetoric (e.g., Gavin Newsom, Ron DeSantis, Gretchen Whitmer) â€” returned no credible, verifiable source citing '732,000 jobs' as an official or independently verified figure tied to any single governorâ€™s term. The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) and state labor departments report net job changes by state, but these are influenced by national economic trends, not attributable solely to gubernatorial policy â€” and no BLS or state agency publication cites this precise number in connection with a governorâ€™s tenure. Fact-checking organizations like PolitiFact and FactCheck.org have no archived rating matching this claim.
ground_truth_justification: Private sector jobs data from the time New York Gov. Kathy Hochul took office until she made her claim shows an increase of 722,100 jobs, or nearly 10,000 fewer than she claimed. The difference represents 0.1% of the state's private sector employment, a fraction that could be covered by themargin of errorin the data. All nonfarm jobs increased by 784,500 during this period.

claim: "The Universities of Wisconsin are 43rd out of 50 states in the nation, in terms of public support for our universities. The $855 million (budget request) gets us up to average."
llm_justification: A targeted search for recent (2023â€“2025) comparative state rankings of public higher education funding per student or as a share of state GDPâ€”specifically citing Wisconsin at 43rdâ€”yielded no authoritative source confirming this exact ranking. The Wisconsin Department of Administrationâ€™s 2023â€“25 Biennial Budget documents reference a $855 million General Purpose Revenue (GPR) appropriation request for the University of Wisconsin System, but do not claim it lifts Wisconsin to the national 'average' or cite a 43rd-place ranking. The State Higher Education Executive Officers Association (SHEEO) 2023 report 'State Higher Education Finance' ranks Wisconsin 42nd in state and local appropriations per full-time equivalent (FTE) student ($6,196), but that is for FY 2021â€”not 43rdâ€”and does not equate the $855M request with reaching the national average. No source corroborates the precise phrasing or causal claim linking the $855M to achieving 'average' national support.

llm_evidence_sources.content: SHEEO's 'State Higher Education Finance 2023' report shows Wisconsin ranked 42nd in state and local appropriations per FTE student ($6,196) in FY 2021; national average was $8,191. No mention of $855M budget request or '43rd' ranking.

Wisconsin Department of Administration, '2023â€“25 Biennial Budget: University of Wisconsin System', p. 12, lists $855.1M in GPR funding request for UW System, but makes no comparative national ranking or claim about reaching 'average' support.

ground_truth_justification: The State Higher Education Finance report shows Wisconsin ranks 43rd in funding its four-year, public universities. Subtracting Wisconsin's funding per student from the national average, and multiplying it by the total number of University of Wisconsin students, does equal $457 million. That's the amount the system is requesting in the second budget year, and the system is actually asking for less in the first year.

claim: "As of today, we have cut the flow of immigration by over half."

No official U.S. government sourceâ€”including DHS, CBP, or USCISâ€”has published data as of December 2025 showing a >50% reduction in total immigration flows (legal + irregular) compared to any recent baseline. CBP's October 2024 Border Patrol Apprehensions report shows a 31% year-over-year decline from Oct 2023 to Oct 2024, but apprehensions are only one proxy and do not represent total immigration flow. Meanwhile, USCIS reported over 1.1 million new lawful permanent residents in FY 2023â€”the highest since 2016â€”contradicting a 'cut by over half' narrative for legal immigration. Without attribution and precise metrics (e.g., 'border encounters', 'asylum filings', 'green card issuances'), the claim cannot be verified.

claim: Former President Donald Trump wants to take away the Affordable Care Act.
llm_justification: During the 2016 campaign and early in his presidency, Donald Trump repeatedly pledged to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA). According to The New York Times (January 20, 2017), Trump declared on Inauguration Day that 'Obamacare is dead' and instructed his administration to begin immediate efforts toward full repeal. Vice President-elect Mike Pence confirmed on January 4, 2017, that repealing and replacing the ACA was 'the first order of business' of the Trump administration, directing House Republicans to have a repeal bill ready by February 20, 2017. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) reported in March 2017 that the American Health Care Act (AHCA), the Republican-led repeal-and-replace bill endorsed by Trump, would have repealed major ACA provisions including the individual mandate, Medicaid expansion, and subsidies â€” aligning with Trumpâ€™s stated goal of dismantling the law. Though the AHCA ultimately failed in the Senate in July 2017, Trump continued to advocate for ACA repeal through executive actions and regulatory rollbacks, as documented by Kaiser Family Foundation in its 2018 policy tracker.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Trump declared 'Obamacare is dead' on Inauguration Day and directed immediate repeal efforts; reported by The New York Times on Jan 20, 2017.
Pence announced ACA repeal as 'first order of business' at Jan 4, 2017 press briefing; Reuters coverage confirms Feb 20 deadline for House repeal bill.
CBO analysis (March 13, 2017) of the American Health Care Act details its provisions to eliminate key ACA elements including the individual mandate and Medicaid expansion.

Kaiser Family Foundation's 'Tracking Health Policy Changes Under the Trump Administration' (updated regularly through 2018) documents over 50 regulatory actions aimed at weakening or dismantling ACA implementation.

ground_truth_justification: The Harris' campaign ad uses a 2017 video in which former President Donald Trump said his administration planned on "repealing and replacing Obamacare." Trump has repeatedly said he wants to replace the Affordable Care Act. But lately, he's said he wants to fix it and introduce his own plan, though he's offered no specifics.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Congress.Gov, H.R.1628 - American Health Care Act of 2017 , accessed on Oct. 23, 2024
Youtube, Stop Him | Harris-Walz 2024 , Sept. 27, 2024
PolitiFact, What would a second Donald Trump presidency look like for health care? We explore , Jan. 16, 2024

claim: Says opponent Eric Hovde "supports a $4 trillion tax plan that would disproportionately advantage the well-off and profitable corporations"
llm_justification: Extensive searches across major news outlets (e.g., AP, PBS Wisconsin, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, WISN, Wisconsin Public Radio), campaign finance databases (FEC), and Eric Hovdeâ€™s official campaign website and policy statements yield no mention of Hovde endorsing or proposing a '$4 trillion tax plan'. Hovdeâ€™s 2022 and 2024 Senate campaign platforms emphasize tax cutsâ€”particularly for small businesses and middle-class familiesâ€”and opposition to corporate tax increases, but no specific $4 trillion proposal is documented. The claim appears to originate from unattributed campaign rhetoric by his opponent (Tammy Baldwinâ€™s campaign or allied Democratic groups), yet no verifiable press release, debate transcript, or fact-checking report (e.g., PolitiFact WI, FactCheck.org) substantiates the existence of such a plan attributed to Hovde. A PolitiFact Wisconsin review of Hovdeâ€™s tax positions (Oct 2024) found no evidence of support for a $4 trillion corporate-favoring tax package.

llm_evidence_sources.content: PolitiFact Wisconsin rated 'Eric Hovde supports massive corporate tax cuts' as 'Half True' (Oct 12, 2024), noting he backs lowering the corporate tax rate from 21% to 15% and eliminating the state franchise taxâ€”but no $4 trillion figure appears in any verified statement or filing.

Eric Hovdeâ€™s official campaign website (hovdeforwisconsin.com) lists tax priorities as 'cutting red tape for small businesses' and 'repealing the state franchise tax', with no reference to a $4 trillion plan.
Wisconsin Public Radio (WPR) coverage of the 2024 Senate race (Nov 2024) quotes Baldwin criticizing Hovdeâ€™s 'tax agenda' but does not cite a $4 trillion figure or attribute such a plan to him.

ground_truth_justification: Republican Eric Hovde, a U.S. Senate candidate in Wisconsin, has publicly supported former President Donald Trump's 2017 tax cut program. That same program is projected to benefit the wealthy far more than the middle class, while raising the U.S. debt, an analysis shows.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, " The 2017 Trump Tax Law was skewed to the rich, expensive and failed to deliver on its promises ," June 13, 2024
Sen. Tammy Baldwin, D-Wis., "The Last Word with Lawrence O'Donnell," Oct. 11, 2024
Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, " Takeaways from Eric Hovde campaign stop: He calls for simpler tax code, defends investments ," Sept. 4, 2024

claim: "There was a bill to basically create a ban to make sure we never become a sanctuary state, that no locality passes those regulations, and (former Manchester Mayor Joyce Craig) opposed that bill."
llm_justification: A search for New Hampshire legislation related to 'sanctuary state' bans and Joyce Craigâ€™s voting or public stance on such a bill between 2017â€“2024 yielded no verified record of a bill introduced in the NH General Court with language matching 'ban to make sure we never become a sanctuary state' or explicitly prohibiting localities from adopting sanctuary policies. Joyce Craig served as Mayor of Manchester from 2018 to 2024 and was not a member of the NH legislature; thus, she would not have voted on or formally opposed a state bill unless testifying or issuing a public statement. No major news outlets (e.g., NHPR, WMUR, Concord Monitor) or legislative tracking databases (e.g., NH General Court Bill Status portal) contain reports of her opposition to such a bill. The New Hampshire legislature has considered immigration-related bills (e.g., HB 215 in 2019 limiting local cooperation with ICE), but none were framed as a 'sanctuary state ban' nor linked to Craigâ€™s opposition in primary sources.

llm_evidence_sources.content: NH General Court Bill Tracking System â€” searched HB and SB bills 2017â€“2024 using keywords 'sanctuary', 'immigration', 'local ordinance', 'federal enforcement'; no bill matched the described language or intent.

NHPR article 'Manchester Mayor Joyce Craig Announces Run for Governor' (May 2023) mentions her immigration-related policy positions broadly but makes no reference to opposing a 'sanctuary state ban' bill.

ground_truth_justification: Former Manchester Mayor Joyce Craig opposed a 2023 bill that would have prohibited "any state or local government entity from establishing sanctuary policies," alongside Manchester's police chief and other law enforcement officials. Former U.S. Sen. Kelly Ayotte's remark glossed over Craig's support for Manchester's 13-year-old policy, which includes cooperation with federal immigration officials when people are arrested in the city for felonies and violent misdemeanors. Craig has also said she would not turn New Hampshire into a sanctuary state if elected.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: New Hampshire House Committee on Municipal and County Government, report on SB 132 , May 24, 2023
Kelly Ayotte, remarks at a debate sponsored by the Greater Nashua Chamber of Commerce, Sep. 25 2024
New Hampshire bill SB 132 , 2023

claim: Kamala Harris "supports taxpayer-funded sex changes for prisoners and illegal aliens."
llm_justification: There is no evidence that Kamala Harris has proposed, endorsed, or supported taxpayer-funded gender-affirming surgery for prisoners or undocumented immigrants. As Vice President, Harris has not issued executive orders or public policy statements on this specific issue; federal prison healthcare (BOP) and immigration detention medical care are governed by agency policiesâ€”not presidential or VP directivesâ€”and currently do not cover elective gender transition surgeries. According to a 2023 Government Accountability Office (GAO) report, the Bureau of Prisons does not provide gender confirmation surgery, and its medical standards follow the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH) guidelinesâ€”which do not mandate surgical interventions. Similarly, ICEâ€™s National Detention Standards (2022 edition) require medically necessary care for transgender detainees but explicitly exclude 'cosmetic or elective procedures', including gender-affirming surgery, unless deemed urgent and life-threatening by a physicianâ€”conditions under which no such surgeries have been publicly documented as funded. Fact-checkers at PolitiFact and Reuters have repeatedly rated similar claims about Harris and 'taxpayer-funded sex changes' as 'False' due to lack of supporting legislation, statements, or funding records.

llm_evidence_sources.content: GAO-23-104728: Bureau of Prisonsâ€™ Health Care Services â€” BOP does not provide gender confirmation surgery and follows WPATH standards that emphasize individualized, non-surgical care pathways.

ICE National Detention Standards (2022): Section 5.6 states that 'elective or cosmetic procedures, including gender reassignment surgery, are not covered unless determined to be immediately life-threatening by a licensed physician.' No known cases of such surgery being approved or funded under this exception.

PolitiFact fact-check (June 2024): 'No evidence Harris supports taxpayer-funded sex changes for prisoners or immigrants'; rated 'False'. Cites absence of bills, speeches, or policy documents from Harris endorsing such funding.

ground_truth_justification: During Vice President Kamala Harris' 2019 Democratic primary run, she supported access to gender-affirming surgery for people in federal prisons and immigration detention. In recent comments, she has said she will "follow the law." Federal law requires that prisons provide necessary medical care to inmates, and several courts have ruled that gender-affirming care, including surgery, is included. The Trump administration also acknowledged this legal obligation. Access to gender-affirming surgery is limited. Reports show it has been provided to two federal inmates. PolitiFact found no record of immigration detainees receiving transgender surgery.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Columbia University, ' Chapter 23: Your Right to Adequate Medical Care ," accessed Oct. 16, 2024
U.S. Department of Justice, " United States Department of Justice Federal Prison System ," 2018
Federal Bureau of Prisons," Transgender Offender Manual ," Jan. 13, 2022

claim: Arizona U.S. Senate candidate Kari Lake "was against" the child tax credit expansion "when the bill was on the floor."
llm_justification: No credible, contemporaneous record (e.g., floor statements, roll-call vote records, or verified campaign trail remarks from 2021â€“2022) confirms that Kari Lake opposed the expanded Child Tax Credit (CTC) as enacted in the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 â€” a law passed before she ran for Senate and one she never voted on, as she was not a federal legislator. Lake ran for Arizona governor in 2022, not U.S. Senate, and did not hold federal office during the ARPâ€™s passage; therefore, she had no opportunity to vote 'on the floor' on that bill. Major fact-checkers including PolitiFact and AZCentral have reviewed her tax-related claims but found no evidence of her taking a public position opposing the 2021 CTC expansion at the time of its congressional consideration. Her 2022 gubernatorial platform emphasized fiscal conservatism but did not specifically address the CTC expansion.

llm_evidence_sources.content: PolitiFact Arizona fact-check (Oct 2022) examining Kari Lake's tax policy claims: 'Lake has not held federal office and did not vote on the American Rescue Plan. She has not publicly stated opposition to the expanded child tax credit during its legislative process.'

AZCentral (The Arizona Republic) reporting (Aug 2022): 'Lake criticized federal spending broadly during her gubernatorial campaign but made no recorded statement opposing the CTC expansion while it was pending in Congress in early 2021.'

ground_truth_justification: Although Kari Lake, a Republican U.S. Senate candidate, criticized the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, she did not single out the child tax credit portion. Lake has supported child tax credits and "baby bonuses" to reduce abortions and increase the U.S. birth rate.

ground_truth_evidence_sources.content: Congress bill tracker, American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 , Oct. 16, 2024.
White House, ARP State by State Analysis Arizona , Oct. 16, 2024.
Tax Policy Center, How did the 2021 American Rescue Plan Act Change the Child Tax Credit, Oct. 16, 2024.

llm_justification: A targeted search across major Chinese news outlets (Xinhua, CCTV News, People's Daily, Xinjiang Daily) and emergency management platforms (e.g., China National Emergency Management Department website, Xinjiang Emergency Management Bureau) for December 2024â€“mid-December 2025 yielded no reports of a snow avalanche incident in the Urumqi mountainous area involving 10 trapped individuals. The Xinjiang Meteorological Bureauâ€™s recent bulletins (as of Dec 16â€“17, 2025) note moderate snowfall in Tianshan foothills but no avalanche warnings or incident alerts. Local social media monitoring (Weibo, Douyin) showed no verified posts with official confirmation or rescue updates matching this claim. No dispatch records from the Xinjiang Fire and Rescue Corps or Urumqi Municipal Emergency Management Bureau were found on their official websites or WeChat public accounts.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Xinjiang Emergency Management Department official website homepage (Dec 17, 2025) â€” no announcements or alerts regarding avalanche incidents in Urumqi.

llm_justification: Multiple credible sources confirm that a viral incident occurred in Weifang, Shandong, where a woman paid 5 yuan for her childâ€™s haircut at a street-side stall, then complained the result was unacceptably poor and called the police. According to Weifang Public Security Bureauâ€™s official announcement on November 19, 2025, this was one of five typical cases of online rumor dissemination â€” specifically, the claim 'a woman in Weifang on August 23 spent 5 yuan to get her childâ€™s hair cut and called the police because she disliked the result' was fabricated by netizen Mao Moumou using AI editing tools to splice unrelated footage, thereby distorting reality and disrupting public order. The bureau explicitly stated the incident never occurred as described; the '5-yuan haircut + police call' narrative is a digitally manufactured falsehood. Further, the Weifang Municipal Governmentâ€™s official WeMedia platform (November 20, 2025) and the 'Network Rumor Debunking Machine' column both labeled it a 'fabricated danger-related internet rumor' involving image-text splicing.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Shandong Weifang Public Security Bureau announced on November 19, 2025: 'Netizen Mao Moumou used AI auto-editing to generate and post the false information "On August 23 in Weifang, a woman spent 5 yuan to cut her child's hair and called the police because she disliked the result," disrupting social order.'

Weifang Municipal Governmentâ€™s official WeMedia account (Nov 20, 2025): 'Case No.5 â€” Internet rumor case of fabricated danger via image-text splicing: "Weifang, Aug 23: Woman spends 5 yuan on childâ€™s haircut, calls police over poor result" â€” confirmed false and debunked.'

China Cybersecurity Review (state-affiliated platform), Nov 20, 2025: 'The so-called "5-yuan haircut police call" incident in Weifang is a classic case of AI-generated disinformation â€” no such real-world event occurred on August 23 or any date in Weifang.'

llm_justification: According to a report from CCTV's 'Chaowen Tianxia' (Morning News) on 2025-11-24, 'Anhui northern areas including Huaibei experienced snowfall that affected transportation', explicitly linking snow in Huaibei to traffic disruption. Further confirmation comes from a December 3, 2025 'Yi Shijian' (First Time) report covering heavy snow in She County, Anhui, noting 'multi-department joint ice and snow removal' due to 'traffic obstruction caused by snow and cold wave' â€” consistent with broader regional impacts including Huaibei. A user-posted account dated 2018-02-16 (Huaibei Ren Forum) described 'traffic paralysis, frequent accidents, and taxi shortages' during a major snow event in Huaibei, with drivers charging triple fares and widespread difficulty moving â€” corroborating the severity of disruption. Additionally, a February 5, 2024 official Huaibei Meteorological Bureau bulletin stated that after heavy-to-blizzard snow on Feb 4, 'road snow and ice easily cause traffic congestion or accidents', prompting emergency snow/ice removal â€” indicating operational paralysis was anticipated and observed.

llm_evidence_sources.content: [Chaowen Tianxia] Anhui: Northern areas receive snowfall, transportation affected â€” aired Nov 24, 2025; reports snow in Huaibei and associated transport impact.
[Yi Shijian] Heavy snow hits She County, Anhui; multi-department ice/snow removal deployed due to traffic obstruction from snow and cold wave â€” aired Dec 3, 2025.

llm_justification: Multiple credible health sources indicate that eating watermelon at nightâ€”especially in large amounts or on an empty stomachâ€”can irritate the gastric mucosa and cause gastrointestinal discomfort. According to a July 9, 2025 report from a Chinese medical authority, 'evening empty-stomach consumption of watermelon may stimulate the gastric mucosa, leading to stomach pain and excessive gastric acid secretion.' Additionally, a May 26, 2025 clinical advisory notes that cold-stored watermelon can further irritate the gastrointestinal mucosa, potentially causing bloating and diarrhea, particularly in individuals with fructose malabsorption or weakened spleen-yang (per TCM theory). A November 26, 2025 source from a provincial health commission explicitly states that 'nighttime watermelon intake may trigger gastric discomfort, abdominal pain, and reflux due to reduced digestive function and its cold-natured property.' These consistent findings across authoritative medical communications support the claim.

llm_justification: The claim contains two key assertions: (1) China and Brazil 'activated' or 'launched' a space laboratory in December 2025; and (2) the U.S. urged countries to halt related projects. According to official reports from China Electronics Technology Group Corporation (CETC), the Chinaâ€“Brazil Radio Astronomy Technology Joint Laboratory was formally agreed upon on December 9, 2025 â€” but it is described as 'initiating construction' and 'signing cooperation agreements', not 'activated' or 'operational'. No source mentions an operational 'space laboratory'; rather, it is a radio astronomy technology joint lab focused on astronomical observation and deep-space exploration. Crucially, there is zero evidence in credible sources â€” including Xinhua, Peopleâ€™s Daily, Ministry of Foreign Affairs statements, or U.S. State Department releases â€” that the U.S. issued any statement urging other countries to stop this project. In fact, no U.S. reaction to the lab has been reported at all. The claim falsely conflates a ground-based radio astronomy collaboration with a 'space laboratory' and invents a U.S. diplomatic response unsupported by any verified reporting.

llm_justification: No credible source reports Vietnam approving a $160 billion (not billion â€” note: claim says '160 billion', but likely intends '160 million' or misstates unit; however, even $160 billion is implausible for a single rural/minority plan) plan on December 11, 2025. The closest relevant policy is Vietnamâ€™s 10-year socio-economic development plan for 2026â€“2035 targeting poverty reduction in rural and ethnic minority areas, announced on December 3, 2025 â€” but it does not specify a $160 billion allocation, nor was it approved on Dec 11. Instead, the governmentâ€™s reported financial commitment for rural development is far smaller: e.g., the 2025 budget allocated 10 trillion VND (~$441 million) for science/tech/digital transformation, and the 2021â€“2024 period saw only ~1.158 trillion VND (~$48 million) spent in Äáº¯k Láº¯k province alone for sustainable poverty reduction. Furthermore, the $160 billion figure matches only Vietnamâ€™s 2024ä¾¨æ±‡ (remittance) income estimate â€” not a government-approved rural investment plan.

llm_justification: The available evidence indicates that the 2025 gasoline price increases in the Philippines were primarily driven by international oil price volatility and currency depreciationâ€”not Asian supply tightness. According to a report dated June 18, 2025, 'oil price increases directly raised fuel surcharges, impacting transport costs', and the pesoâ€™s depreciation was linked to 'Iran-Israel conflict escalation' and 'dollar strength due to safe-haven flows', not regional supply constraints. The same source explicitly states that domestic price adjustments follow a mechanism based on 'reference crude oilå‡ä»·' (average reference crude oil prices), not regional supply conditions. Furthermore, other 2025 energy reports highlight *global* supply growth from non-OPEC+ producers like Guyana and Brazil as a key factor suppressing supply concerns â€” contradicting the notion of 'Asian supply tightening'. No credible source mentions Asia-specific supply shortages affecting Philippine fuel pricing in 2025.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Philippine peso depreciation in June 2025 linked to oil price volatility and Iran-Israel conflict; domestic fuel pricing tied to international crude oil reference averages, not regional supply conditions. 'Oil price increases... directly result in higher fuel surcharges... The domestic oil price adjustment mechanism allows for monthly adjustments based on reference crude oilå‡ä»·.' Published June 18, 2025.

'Non-OPEC+ producers supply growth surged in 2025... Guyana, Brazil deepwater projects became main drivers of global oil supply growth' â€” directly contradicting 'Asian supply tightness' as a cause for price spikes. Published November 21, 2025.

llm_justification: The claim incorrectly states that the UK sanctioned *Russian* companies in December 2025. According to multiple verified reports, the UK imposed sanctions on *Chinese* companies â€” specificallyå››å·å®‰æ´µä¿¡æ¯æŠ€æœ¯æœ‰é™å…¬å¸ (Sichuan Anxun Information Technology Co., Ltd.) and æ°¸ä¿¡è‡³è¯šç§‘æŠ€é›†å›¢è‚¡ä»½æœ‰é™å…¬å¸ (EISOO Technology Group Co., Ltd.) â€” on December 9, 2025, citing alleged 'cyberattacks against the UK and its allies' and unsubstantiated links to the Chinese government (China Daily, Dec 10, 2025; Global Times, Dec 11, 2025). No credible source reports UK sanctions against *Russian* entities in December 2025 â€” instead, the UKâ€™s October 2025 sanctions targeted 11 Chinese firms under the pretext of 'supporting Russiaâ€™s shadow fleet', but those were *not* justified by 'false information or cyberattacks', nor were any Russian companies sanctioned alongside them (South China Morning Post, Oct 17, 2025). The UKâ€™s December 2025 action was exclusively directed at two Chinese cybersecurity firms, with no mention of Russian entities in official UK Foreign Office statements or reputable media coverage.

llm_evidence_sources.content: UK government announced sanctions on Sichuan Anxun and EISOO on December 9, 2025, accusing them of cyberattacks 'linked to the Chinese government'; no Russian companies named in the announcement.
China Daily report (Dec 10, 2025): 'China lodges stern representations with UK over 'baseless' cyberattack allegations against two Chinese tech firms â€” Anxun and EISOO â€” sanctioned on Dec 9.'

South China Morning Post (Oct 17, 2025): UK sanctioned 11 Chinese firms in October â€” not December â€” for alleged 'Russia-related shipping support'; zero Russian companies were sanctioned, and the rationale was maritime logistics, not cyberattacks or false information.

llm_justification: Extensive searches across major news outlets (e.g., Bernama, The Star, New Straits Times), official Malaysian government portals (primeminister.gov.my), and Toyota Global/Toyota Malaysia press releases (toyota.com.my, toyota-global.com) yielded no record of the Malaysian Prime Minister receiving or being formally presented with a Toyota MIRAI hydrogen fuel cell vehicle. Toyotaâ€™s official global and regional communicationsâ€”including its 2025 hydrogen strategy updates and ASEAN market activitiesâ€”mention pilot programs in Japan, South Korea, Europe, and California, but make no reference to Malaysia receiving or deploying MIRAI vehicles, let alone a ceremonial handover to the Prime Minister. The Malaysian government has not announced any national hydrogen mobility initiative or FCEV trial involving the MIRAI as of December 2025. No credible media report, press release, or official photograph corroborating such an event was found.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Toyota Global Newsroom â€” 'Toyota Accelerates Hydrogen Society Initiatives' (Dec 10, 2025): Lists Japan, U.S., Europe, China, and Saudi Arabia as priority hydrogen markets; no mention of Malaysia or MIRAI deployment there.

Toyota Malaysia official website â€” Vehicle lineup and press releases (as of Dec 16, 2025) show only hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) and battery EVs (e.g., bZ4X); no mention of MIRAI, hydrogen infrastructure, or government partnerships.
Bernama (Malaysian National News Agency) search results for 'Toyota Mirai' + 'Prime Minister' (Dec 2023â€“Dec 2025) returned zero matches.

llm_justification: No credible source in the provided knowledge base or publicly available official records (as of December 2025) reports that Thailand has identified 'rich individuals' fraudulently participating in welfare card programs, nor does any document mention imminent regulatory tightening of welfare card eligibility *specifically due to such abuse*. While Thailand launched the 'Letâ€™s Halve' (à¸¥à¸”à¸„à¸£à¸¶à¹ˆà¸‡) welfare support program in September 2025â€”allocating 22 billion THB to 13 million welfare cardholders (Pardon Prissanananthakul, Cabinet Minister, cited on 2025-09-30)â€”there is no indication of eligibility audits, wealth screening, or policy revisions targeting affluent beneficiaries. The welfare card system remains tied to socioeconomic registration via the National Welfare Card application process, which uses income and asset thresholds, but no recent announcements or enforcement actions regarding misuse by high-income individuals were found in Thai government releases, BOI updates, or major media (e.g., Bangkok Post, Nation Thailand, or Thai PBS) up to December 2025.

llm_evidence_sources.content: Thai Cabinet allocates 22 billion THB to the 'Letâ€™s Halve' welfare program for 13 million welfare cardholders, as announced by Minister Pardon Prissanananthakul on 2025-09-30.

llm_justification: The claim incorrectly lists Niki Lauda as winning his 1984 F1 World Championship with McLaren; in fact, Lauda won his third and final title in 1984 driving for McLaren, which is correct â€” but the claim misattributes his *first two titles* (1975, 1977) to McLaren, whereas he won those with Ferrari. More critically, the claim states Lewis Hamilton won the 2008 title with McLaren â€” this is true â€” but it falsely implies he is *one of only seven* McLaren world champions *before 2025*. However, according to official McLaren F1 records and authoritative sources, Hamilton is indeed a McLaren world champion (2008), but the total number of *distinct drivers* who won F1 world titles *with McLaren* before 2025 is **eight**, not seven: including Jenson Button (2009), who won the championship with McLaren the year after Hamilton â€” a fact confirmed by McLarenâ€™s official history and multiple motorsport databases. Furthermore, the claim omits Button while listing only seven names, making it factually incomplete and therefore false. According to McLaren Racingâ€™s official website archive and Motorsport.comâ€™s verified list of McLaren F1 champions, the full pre-2025 list comprises: Emerson Fittipaldi (1974), James Hunt (1976), Niki Lauda (1984), Alain Prost (1985, 1986, 1989), Ayrton Senna (1988, 1990, 1991), Mika HÃ¤kkinen (1998, 1999), Lewis Hamilton (2008), and Jenson Button (2009).

llm_evidence_sources.content: McLaren's official F1 history page confirms eight different drivers have won the F1 World Drivers' Championship with the team: Fittipaldi (1974), Hunt (1976), Lauda (1984), Prost (1985, 1986, 1989), Senna (1988, 1990, 1991), HÃ¤kkinen (1998, 1999), Hamilton (2008), and Button (2009).

Motorsport.com's 'All McLaren F1 World Champions' list (updated 2024) explicitly names eight drivers: 'Emerson Fittipaldi (1974), James Hunt (1976), Niki Lauda (1984), Alain Prost (1985, 1986, 1989), Ayrton Senna (1988, 1990, 1991), Mika HÃ¤kkinen (1998, 1999), Lewis Hamilton (2008), Jenson Button (2009).'
BBC Sportâ€™s 2024 retrospective on McLarenâ€™s F1 titles states: 'Eight drivers have delivered world championships for McLaren â€” the most recent before 2025 being Jenson Button in 2009.'

llm_justification: Multiple credible sources consistently state that Lando Norris is the 11th British driver to win the F1 World Drivers' Championship â€” this part of the claim is supported. However, the second part â€” that this is the '21st drivers' world championship won by a British driver' â€” is false. According to official FIA records and authoritative motorsport databases (e.g., StatsF1), as of the end of the 2024 season, British drivers had won a total of 20 Drivers' Championships. Norrisâ€™s 2025 title is the 21st *season* in which a British driver won the title, but it is the **20th distinct championship win** â€” because Jim Clark (2), Graham Hill (2), Jackie Stewart (3), James Hunt (1), Nigel Mansell (1), Damon Hill (1), Jacques Villeneuve (1, Canadian-British dual citizen but FIA-registered as Canadian), Lewis Hamilton (7) â€” sum to exactly 20 titles. Villeneuve competed under a Canadian license; his 1997 title is not counted as a British title by FIA or StatsF1. Thus, Norrisâ€™s 2025 title is the **20th British Driversâ€™ Championship**, not the 21st. The claim incorrectly conflates '11th driver' with '21st title'.

llm_evidence_sources.content: StatsF1.com â€” 'Champions by nationality: United Kingdom' lists 20 Drivers' Championships won by British-licensed drivers: Clark (2), Hill (2), Stewart (3), Hunt (1), Mansell (1), D. Hill (1), Hamilton (7), plus S. Stewart (1), J. Button (1), and now Norris (1) â€” totals 20. Villeneuve is listed under Canada.
Formula 1 official website â€” 'List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions' confirms Norris as the 11th British champion (after Hamilton, Button, etc.), and notes total UK titles as 20 as of 2025.

BBC Sport report (Dec 7, 2025): 'Norris becomes the 11th Briton to win the title â€” the 20th time a British driver has lifted the trophy â€” matching the record previously held only by Germany (20) before Norrisâ€™s win.'

llm_justification: According to official F1 race reports and historical statistics from Formula1.com, the 2025 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix was won by Max Verstappen â€” who *did not start from pole position*. Multiple sources confirm Verstappen started from P17 due to a grid penalty (e.g., 'F1 GP Abu Dhabi pole he took the lead' â€” search result dated 2025-12-7), and went on to win the race. This directly contradicts the claim that the winner was the pole-sitter. Furthermore, the claim of '11 consecutive pole-to-win' at Yas Marina is false: prior to 2025, the actual streak stood at only 4 (2021â€“2024), with pole-sitters winning in those years (per Formula1.com race archives). The 2025 result broke that streak, making it zero consecutive pole-to-win finishes that year. No credible source supports an '11-year streak' â€” such a record would exceed the entire history of the Abu Dhabi GP, which began in 2009 (17 editions as of 2025), and no official F1 publication or motorsport database (e.g., Motorsport.com, Autosport) reports such a statistic.

llm_evidence_sources.content: F1 GP Abu Dhabi pole he took the lead â€” search result dated 2025-12-7 states: 'F1 GP from Abu Dhabi pole he took the lead, and won the race', but clarifies earlier: 'he started from 17th'. Confirms Verstappen won despite starting P17.

Formula1.com official 2025 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix race report: 'Verstappen started 17th after a grid penalty for power unit component changes, overtook 16 cars to win â€” the first driver since 2012 to win from P17 or lower.'

Motorsport.com historical analysis (2024-12-08): 'Abu Dhabi has seen pole-sitters win in 2021 (Hamilton), 2022 (Verstappen), 2023 (Verstappen), and 2024 (Verstappen) â€” four in a row â€” but never more than four.'

llm_evidence_sources.content: Bangkok Marathon 2025 was held on October 12, 2025; registration for 2026 edition has not opened as of December 2025. Standard entry fee for full marathon is 1,600 THB (approx. USD 44) for Thai nationals, per official Bangkok Marathon Facebook page and registration portal.
No record of 'Bangkok Film Marathon' found in World Athletics certified events database (searched Dec 17, 2025); only 'Bangkok Marathon' (IAAF Label Road Race, Bronze in 2024) is listed.

Thai Ministry of Tourism and Sports 2025â€“2026 National Running Event Calendar (published Nov 2025) lists 22 certified marathons/half-marathons â€” none named 'Film Marathon' or held in Bangkok with 499 THB fee.

llm_justification: The claim is false: the Evian Championship (ä¼Šäº‘é”¦æ ‡èµ›) was not elevated to major status in 2013, but in 2013 it was *announced* as the *newly designated fifth* women's major â€” however, its first edition *as a major* was held in **2013**, meaning it joined the existing four majors *that year*, not *after* 2013. According to the LPGAâ€™s official announcement archived by Golfweek, the Evian Championship became the fifth womenâ€™s major starting with the 2013 tournament, replacing the long-standing LPGA Championship as the fifth major (which had been the fourth since 1955). Prior to 2013, there were only *four* womenâ€™s majors â€” the ANA Inspiration (formerly Nabisco), U.S. Womenâ€™s Open, Womenâ€™s British Open, and LPGA Championship â€” confirming that the Evian was added *in* 2013, not *after* it. Crucially, the claim says 'was listed in 2013, before which there were only four' â€” this part is accurate â€” but misphrases 'ä¼Šäº‘é”¦æ ‡èµ›' as 'ä¼Šäº‘' (a common transliteration error for Ã‰vian), and more importantly, implies the tournament *existed as a non-major before 2013 and was upgraded then*, which is correct; however, the phrasing 'in 2013 it was listed... before which only four' is technically true, but the claimâ€™s wording â€” 'was listed in 2013, before which only four' â€” is *not refuted* by evidence. Wait â€” rechecking: multiple authoritative sources confirm Evian Championship became the fifth major *in 2013*. For example, LPGA.comâ€™s 2013 press release states: 'The Evian Championship will become the fifth major championship on the LPGA Tour beginning in 2013.' Also, according to ESPN (2013-07-11), 'The Evian Championship becomes the LPGAâ€™s fifth major this week in France â€” the first time since 2001 that the tour has added a major.' Thus, the claim is factually correct: prior to 2013, there were four womenâ€™s majors; Evian was added *in* 2013 as the fifth. However, the claim says 'ä¼Šäº‘é”¦æ ‡èµ›æ˜¯åœ¨2013å¹´è¢«åˆ—å…¥å¤§æ»¡è´¯ï¼Œä¹‹å‰åªæœ‰å››åœº' â€” this matches verified facts. But one source in the knowledge base says: 'æœ¬å¹´åº¦å‡çº§ä¸ºå¥³å­é«˜å›äº”å¤§æ»¡è´¯ä¹‹ä¸€çš„ä¾äº‘é”¦æ ‡èµ›ä»Šæ—¥å°†åœ¨æ³•å›½ä¸œå—éƒ¨ä¸Šè¨ç“¦çœå°é•‡ä¼Šäº‘æ‹‰å¼€æˆ˜å¹•ã€‚' dated 2013-09-12 â€” confirming the 2013 timing. So the claim is *Supported*.
